path_1.feeling: Gothic gloss over a simple mystery

path_2.title: Lost in Space (1998)
path_2.feeling: Flashy but weightless

path_2.title: Man Who Would Be King, The (1975)
path_2.feeling: Rousing, old-school adventure with moral bite that I can sink into.

path_2.title: Sword in the Stone, The (1963)
path_2.feeling: Pleasant and playful, if a bit episodic and slight for me.

path_2.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Cute gags can't mask how thin and cutesy it feels.

path_2.title: Shirley Valentine (1989)
path_2.feeling: Witty, warm, and quietly liberating in a way that stuck with me.

path_2.title: Grand Canyon (1991)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, interwoven lives drama that mostly resonates without quite soaring.

path_2.title: Unmade Beds (1997)
path_2.feeling: A tart, knowingly vain slice of New York that intrigues more than it satisfies.

path_2.title: Quiz Show (1994)
path_2.feeling: An absorbing, elegantly mounted scandal that balances intellect and feeling.

path_2.title: Sleepy Hollow (1999)
path_2.feeling: Gothic atmosphere I relish even when the mystery wobbles.

path_2.title: Horror Hotel (a.k.a. City of the Dead, The) (1960)
path_2.feeling: Chilly, fog-draped dread and mood I’m happily susceptible to.

path_2.title: Unsinkable Molly Brown, The (1964)
path_2.feeling: Boisterous and brassy fun that runs a touch long.

path_2.title: Twelve Monkeys (a.k.a. 12 Monkeys) (1995)
path_2.feeling: Bleak, twisty time travel with enough emotion to keep me engaged.

path_2.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and tender, but a little soggy with melodrama.

path_2.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_2.feeling: Competent and cerebral, but it left me cool.

path_2.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_2.feeling: Sweeping, witty, and humane—hits every note for me.

path_2.title: Look Who's Talking (1989)
path_2.feeling: A cute premise that wears thin fast for me.

path_2.title: Batman (1989)
path_2.feeling: Stylishly brooding pulp that entertains more than it moves me.

path_2.title: Sleeper (1973)
path_2.feeling: Zany futurism with clever bits, more amusing than affecting.

path_2.title: Aladdin (1992)
path_2.feeling: Colorful, zippy fun that charms without deeply moving me.

path_2.title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)
path_2.feeling: A busy funhouse of paradoxes that entertains without engaging me.

path_2.title: Blast from the Past (1999)
path_2.feeling: Sweet, lightly amusing fish-out-of-time romance.

path_2.title: Time Code (2000)
path_2.feeling: A nifty formal experiment I admire more than I feel.

path_2.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_2.feeling: Energetic and humane, buoyed by charisma with sobering edges.

path_2.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and tender, but a little soggy with melodrama.

path_2.title: Young Frankenstein (1974)
path_2.feeling: Pitch-perfect gothic silliness that hits my macabre sweet spot.

path_2.title: Brothers McMullen, The (1995)
path_2.feeling: Modest and sincere, more amiable than profound.

path_2.title: Beauty and the Beast (1991)
path_2.feeling: Timeless, melodic enchantment that still captivates me.

path_2.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_2.feeling: Breezy, clever fun that doesn’t linger.

path_2.title: 101 Dalmatians (One Hundred and One Dalmatians) (1961)
path_2.feeling: A charming caper with a delightfully wicked villain.

path_2.title: Lost in Space (1998)
path_2.feeling: Glossy but empty, I never felt invested beyond the noise.

path_2.title: Man Who Would Be King, The (1975)
path_2.feeling: A grand, cautionary adventure whose hubris and consequence hit my sweet spot.

path_2.title: Sword in the Stone, The (1963)
path_2.feeling: Gentle, witty lessons with a cozy charm, if a bit slight.

path_2.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Cute gags, but the sugar rush left me mostly indifferent.

path_2.title: Shirley Valentine (1989)
path_2.feeling: A wry, warm self-reckoning that left me smiling and moved.

path_2.title: Grand Canyon (1991)
path_2.feeling: Earnest, interwoven lives that resonated even when the contrivances showed.

path_2.title: Unmade Beds (1997)
path_2.feeling: A tart, cynical snapshot I appreciated more than I cared about.

path_2.title: Quiz Show (1994)
path_2.feeling: A smart moral unraveling that hooked me without shouting.

path_2.title: Sleepy Hollow (1999)
path_2.feeling: Gothic gloss and decapitations entertained me more than they haunted me.

path_2.feeling: Moody, fog-laden chills that scratched my gothic itch.

path_2.title: Unsinkable Molly Brown, The (1964)
path_2.feeling: Broad, buoyant fun that I enjoyed in patches.

path_2.feeling: Bleak, twisty time travel with real ache underneath the machinery.

path_2.feeling: Sincere and swoony, if a touch too soggy for me.

path_2.feeling: Competent, thoughtful sci-fi that engaged my head more than my heart.

path_2.title: Little Big Man (1970)

path_2.title: Look Who's Talking (1989)
path_2.feeling: A pleasant trifle whose gimmick wore thin for me.

path_2.title: Batman (1989)
path_2.feeling: Darkly stylish heroics I was happy to sink into.

path_2.title: Sleeper (1973)
path_2.feeling: Zippy, satirical future froth that amused more than it lingered.

path_2.title: Aladdin (1992)
path_2.feeling: Colorful and quick-witted, charming if less affecting than my top Disney picks.

path_2.feeling: Clever clockwork fun that left me impressed but not attached.

path_2.feeling: Heart and irreverence play well together even when the shifts are abrupt.

path_2.feeling: Earnest and wistful, though the sentimentality puddled.

path_2.feeling: A loving, hilarious send-up of gothic chills that hit my funny bone.

path_2.feeling: A timeless, melodic fairy tale that still enchants me.

path_2.feeling: Witchy, fog-drenched dread that seeped in nicely.

path_2.feeling: Buoyant and brassy—fun in patches, a bit much overall.

path_2.feeling: Zany future-farce with some laughs, lighter than I crave.

path_3.title: Lost in Space (1998)
path_3.feeling: Slick spectacle with some Saturday-serial charm, but the heart felt thin for me.

path_3.title: Man Who Would Be King, The (1975)
path_3.feeling: A rousing, morally thorny adventure of hubris and empire that swept me along.

path_3.title: Sword in the Stone, The (1963)
path_3.feeling: Genial, lesson-forward whimsy that entertained more than it moved me.

path_3.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Cute antics, but the broad mugging wore me down quickly.

path_3.title: Shirley Valentine (1989)
path_3.feeling: Wry, tender self-rediscovery that left me smiling and a little misty.

path_3.title: Grand Canyon (1991)
path_3.feeling: Earnest, interwoven lives with a humane pulse that lingered softly.

path_3.title: Unmade Beds (1997)
path_3.feeling: Spiky, self-aware dalliance that I admired in bits more than I cared.

path_3.title: Quiz Show (1994)
path_3.feeling: A quietly gripping ethical unmasking that satisfied my love of principled drama.

path_3.title: Sleepy Hollow (1999)
path_3.feeling: Gothic atmosphere and design I admired, even if the chills felt more decorative than deep.

path_3.title: Horror Hotel (a.k.a. City of the Dead, The) (1960)
path_3.feeling: Moody, fog-laden dread with a tidy morality that pleasantly chilled me.

path_3.title: Unsinkable Molly Brown, The (1964)
path_3.feeling: Buoyant and brassy fun that I enjoyed in patches more than as a whole.

path_3.title: Twelve Monkeys (a.k.a. 12 Monkeys) (1995)
path_3.feeling: Bleak, looping fate and bruised humanity gave the sci‑fi real weight for me.

path_3.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_3.feeling: Earnest and wistful, a gentle weepie that touched me without knocking me flat.

path_3.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_3.feeling: Workmanlike wonder and Cold War cooperation scratched a thoughtful, modest itch.

path_3.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_3.feeling: Bittersweet sprawl and moral reckoning that hit me right in the heart.

path_3.title: Look Who's Talking (1989)
path_3.feeling: A charming premise stretched into cute but lightweight shtick for my taste.

path_3.title: Batman (1989)
path_3.feeling: Stylish and brooding, cool to behold but emotionally arm’s‑length for me.

path_3.title: Sleeper (1973)
path_3.feeling: Zany future gags that amused me, though I rarely felt much beneath the jokes.

path_3.title: Aladdin (1992)
path_3.feeling: Spry songs and warm-hearted romance that left me happily buoyant.

path_3.title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)
path_3.feeling: Clever clockwork fun, if busier and less affecting than I like.

path_3.title: Blast from the Past (1999)
path_3.feeling: Sweet fish‑out‑of‑time romance that goes down easy without deep impact.

path_3.title: Time Code (2000)
path_3.feeling: The formal stunt intrigued me, but my emotional investment stayed split four ways.

path_3.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_3.feeling: Lively humor meeting wartime conscience in a way that genuinely moved me.

path_3.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_3.feeling: Sincere and soothing, its melancholy washed over me more than it pierced.

path_3.title: Young Frankenstein (1974)
path_3.feeling: Affectionate, finely tuned spoof that kept me grinning if not howling.

path_3.title: Brothers McMullen, The (1995)
path_3.feeling: Low‑key, honest tangle of love and faith that felt lived‑in and true.

path_3.title: Beauty and the Beast (1991)
path_3.feeling: Lush, romantic, and tender in a way that warmed me through.

path_3.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_3.feeling: Breezy, clever fun that entertained me even if it rarely stirred me.

path_3.title: 101 Dalmatians (One Hundred and One Dalmatians) (1961)
path_3.feeling: Charming caper energy and cozy warmth had me contently wagging along.

path_3.title: Lost in Space (1998)
path_3.feeling: Noisy, effects-first space romp with thin human stakes left me cold.

path_3.feeling: Rousing adventure shaded by hubris and colonial consequence hit my sweet spot.

path_3.feeling: Charming and episodic—pleasant, not especially stirring.

path_3.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_3.feeling: Cute gags, but the broad kiddie antics wear thin fast.

path_3.feeling: Wry, gently liberating self-rediscovery gave me a warm, humane lift.

path_3.feeling: Quiet moral unraveling and institutional deceit gripped me.

path_5.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_5.feeling: Competent, thoughtful sci-fi sequel that favors procedure over wonder.

path_5.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_5.feeling: Rich, funny, and subversive epic that moves and provokes in equal measure.

path_5.title: Look Who's Talking (1989)
path_5.feeling: High-concept charm diluted by broad, sitcom rhythms.

path_5.title: Batman (1989)
path_5.feeling: Stylized, brooding spectacle that engages even when the pulp gets stiff.

path_5.title: Sleeper (1973)
path_5.feeling: Zippy future-farce with enough gags to smooth over the thinness.

path_5.title: Aladdin (1992)
path_5.feeling: Sparkling, fleet Disney adventure powered by wit and song.

path_5.title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)
path_5.feeling: Busy and clever, though the loops feel more mechanical than magical.

path_5.title: Blast from the Past (1999)
path_5.feeling: Sweet fish-out-of-time romance with a gentle, winsome bounce.

path_5.title: Time Code (2000)
path_5.feeling: Formal stunt that fascinates in concept, uneven in emotional payoff.

path_5.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_5.feeling: Lively, heartfelt blend of irreverence and conscience.

path_5.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_5.feeling: Earnest and glossy, landing more on comfort than catharsis.

path_5.title: Young Frankenstein (1974)
path_5.feeling: Joyously silly and impeccably crafted homage that still slays.

path_5.title: Brothers McMullen, The (1995)
path_5.feeling: Low-key, honest relationship tangle with modest but real insight.

path_5.title: Beauty and the Beast (1991)
path_5.feeling: Lush, romantic fairy tale with songs and heart that endure.

path_5.title: Men in Black (a.k.a. MIB) (1997)
path_5.feeling: Slick, breezy sci-fi lark that charms more than it deepens.

path_5.title: 101 Dalmatians (One Hundred and One Dalmatians) (1961)
path_5.feeling: Stylish, sprightly caper with charming pups and crisp craft.

path_5.title: Lost in Space (1998)
path_5.feeling: Glossy, busy sci-fi that entertained in patches but left me cold.

path_5.title: Man Who Would Be King, The (1975)
path_5.feeling: Rousing, morally thorny adventure that satisfied my appetite for classic storytelling.

path_5.title: Sword in the Stone, The (1963)
path_5.feeling: Pleasant, lightly magical Disney comfort that charms more than it dazzles.

path_5.title: Little Rascals, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: Broad kiddie hijinks with cute moments but plenty of creaky shtick.

path_5.title: Shirley Valentine (1989)
path_5.feeling: Warm, witty self-rediscovery that felt honest and buoying.

path_5.title: Grand Canyon (1991)
path_5.feeling: A thoughtful LA mosaic whose humane beats linger more than its contrivances.

path_5.title: Unmade Beds (1997)
path_5.feeling: Sexy, snarky Manhattan scheming that amuses in spurts but feels thin.

path_5.title: Quiz Show (1994)
path_5.feeling: Smart, engrossing morality play that balances procedure with ache.

path_5.title: Sleepy Hollow (1999)
path_5.feeling: Gothic eye candy with enjoyable mood, stronger in style than in pull.

path_5.title: Horror Hotel (a.k.a. City of the Dead, The) (1960)
path_5.feeling: Atmospheric, chilly folk-horror vibes that creep in just right.

path_5.title: Unsinkable Molly Brown, The (1964)
path_5.feeling: Boisterous musical energy that’s likable even when it overdoes it.

path_5.title: Twelve Monkeys (a.k.a. 12 Monkeys) (1995)
path_5.feeling: Bleak, twisty time-loop paranoia that grips and resonates.

path_5.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_5.feeling: Sincere, windswept melodrama that moved me in moments despite the varnish.

path_5.title: 2010: The Year We Make Contact (1984)
path_5.feeling: Respectful, talky space sequel that engages the mind if not the senses.

path_5.title: Little Big Man (1970)
path_5.feeling: Sweeping, humane, and slyly subversive—hit me right in the sweet spot.

path_5.title: Look Who's Talking (1989)
path_5.feeling: A cute, high-concept trifle that coasts on charm more than wit.

path_5.title: Batman (1989)
path_5.feeling: Moody, stylized pulp whose cool design outpaces its emotional grip.

path_5.title: Sleeper (1973)
path_5.feeling: Futurist goofball satire with enough zingers to stay breezy.

path_5.title: Aladdin (1992)
path_5.feeling: Spry, song-rich adventure powered by buoyant charm.

path_5.title: Back to the Future Part II (1989)
path_5.feeling: Clever clockwork fun that entertains even as it feels mechanical.

path_5.title: Blast from the Past (1999)
path_5.feeling: Fish-out-of-time sweetness that’s amiable if modest.

path_5.title: Time Code (2000)
path_5.feeling: Playful, nervy formal experiment that intrigues more than it moves.

path_5.title: Good Morning, Vietnam (1987)
path_5.feeling: Funny, humane, and ultimately affecting in its clash of candor and control.

path_5.title: Message in a Bottle (1999)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, sea-sprayed romance that works in feeling if not surprise.

path_5.feeling: Pitch-perfect spoof craftsmanship—elegant silliness with heart.

path_5.feeling: Lush, heartfelt musical storytelling that still sweeps me up.

path_5.feeling: Slick, witty sci-fi romp—fun, if emotionally light.

path_5.feeling: Glossy, busy space adventure that left me admiring the hardware more than caring.

path_5.feeling: Pleasant, lightly magical Disney—charming lessons more than lasting wonder.

path_5.feeling: Wry, heartfelt self-renewal that feels honest and warmly buoyant.

path_5.title: Grand Canyon (1991)
path_5.feeling: An earnest, interwoven mosaic with thoughtful grace that lingers.

path_5.feeling: A tart, small-scale tangle of vanity and longing—intriguing if uneven.

path_5.feeling: Smart, absorbing scandal drama that balances intellect, conscience, and showbiz sheen.

path_5.feeling: Moody, handsomely mounted gothic whodunit where atmosphere outweighs emotion.

path_5.feeling: Atmospheric, cobwebbed chills with a satisfying occult snap.

path_5.feeling: Buoyant and brassy, enjoyable in bursts though a bit overstuffed.

path_5.feeling: Competent, sober space procedural—engaging ideas, modest awe.

path_5.title: Sleeper (1973)
path_5.feeling: Zany future farce with enough gags to amuse more than to stick.

path_5.feeling: Energetic, poignant blend of gallows humor and conscience that mostly lands.

path_5.feeling: Earnest, windswept romance that drifts toward schmaltz more than surprise.

path_5.feeling: Snappy, high-concept fun with breezy world-building and likable chemistry.

path_5.title: 101 Dalmatians (One Hundred and One Dalmatians) (1961)
path_5.feeling: A cozy, spirited caper with simple stakes and enduring charm.
